description: Vase-shaped cap with blunt branching ridges that run down the stem (not true gills). Uniform egg-yellow color throughout with dense, pale white flesh inside. Distinctive fruity apricot aroma is key identifier.
habitat: Conifer forests near Pacific coast, most commonly with western conifers. Prefers mature forests with stable moisture and well-established mycorrhizal networks.
season: Pacific Northwest: July-November, Midwest: Late June-October, Northeast: June-October. Peak season typically July-August.
lookalikes: Hygrophoropsis aurantiaca (False Chanterelle) - MILDLY POISONOUS - has true thin gills, brighter orange with darker center
Omphalotus species (Jack-o'-Lantern) - TOXIC - has thin, deep, delicate true gills that cause severe gastrointestinal distress
safety_notes: Key identifiers: blunt ridges (not thin gills), white interior, fruity apricot scent. Always verify ridges are thick and forked, not thin separate gills like poisonous lookalikes.
